procedure.summary: Place your ham joint in a saucepan and cover it with water.
procedure.description: Grab a saucepan or similar cooking pot that’s large enough to hold your ham joint. Place the gammon inside the pan, then pour in enough water to cover the entire cut of meat. For extra taste, use a flavored liquid like perry or cider instead of water.

procedure.summary: Add herbs, fruits, and other ingredients to taste.
procedure.description: To give your gammon additional flavor characteristics, add in a variety of cooking ingredients you think taste good with ham. This may include anything from herbs and vegetables to fruits and citrus. Use ingredients like sliced onions, sliced lemons, peppercorns, and bay leaves to give your gammon a rich, hearty flavor. Try adding apple, orange, or pear slices to give your gammon the fun, fruity flavor many associate with the holidays.

procedure.summary: Bring your saucepan to a boil, then lower the heat and put a lid on it.
procedure.description: Place your saucepan on a stove or burner and set the temperature to high. Once the water starts to boil, lower the temperature to bring the water to a simmer. Then, place a cooking lid on top of the saucepan. The lid will trap in steam, helping your ham joint retain moisture.

procedure.summary: Let the dish simmer for 25 minutes per 1.1 lb (500 g) of gammon.
procedure.description: Your cooking time will depend entirely on how large your ham joint is. Small joints may only need to boil for 30 minutes to an hour, but large joints can take 2 hours or more. Cooking time may vary between kitchens, so check your gammon often to make sure it doesn’t overcook.

procedure.summary: Check the ham joint regularly and remove any excess froth.
procedure.description: While cooking, check on your ham joint every 15 to 30 minutes. If any froth or scum rises to the surface, scoop it up using a cooking spoon and discard it in your sink.

procedure.summary: Remove your gammon when you can easily pierce it with a fork.
procedure.description: Before taking out your ham joint, grab a general purpose fork or knife and press it into the thickest part of the dish. If your utensil goes in and out of the gammon with no resistance, it’s ready to eat. If the meat is still tough, it needs to cook a little longer.

procedure.summary: Give your gammon 15 minutes to rest before serving it.
procedure.description: After you remove your ham joint from the pan, set it on a large plate and let it finish cooking for about 15 minutes. Then, feel free to carve and serve it. If you have any leftovers, place them inside an airtight container and store them in your fridge for 3 to 4 days.
